name: Aerosol Optical Depth
content:
Description: Data on the amount of aerosols in the air over Washington, DC from 2000-2021

Source: [Adapted Lesson](https://drive.google.com/drive/folders/1gZFP5AlIEPwCVOjmPpYOrN1wz5ymUOan?usp=sharing) via [My NASA Data](https://mynasadata.larc.nasa.gov/)

[Educator-Facing Datasheet](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1J89nBC2MUoiuLJf6SDMAKw_IvuaUArrnpiLRIZrZRAU/edit?usp=sharing)

Columns:

* CITY (string): Name of city
* STATE (string): Name of state
* DATE (string): Date in month/day/year format
* TIME (numerical): The month of the date (1-12)
* LONGITUDE (numerical): Longitude for measurement
* LATITUDE (string): Latitude for measurement
* OPTICAL_DEPTH_AVERAGE (numerical): The aerosol optical depth is related to how much light is absorbed or scattered by aerosols (i.e., sea salt, dust, volcanic ash, sulfates, nitrates, black carbon, etc.) in the Atmosphere. Different aerosols scatter or absorb sunlight to varying degrees, depending on their physical properties. The higher the optical depth, the more light is absorbed or scattered by aerosols. These data have a grid spacing of 0.5 degrees longitude and 0.5 degrees latitude. UNITS: Since the optical depth is a ratio of incoming light to the light scattered by aerosols, it is a quantity that has no units (dimensionless).
